image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price speaks at a podium at the National Press Club

items.synopsis: Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price fronts the National Press Club as the Voice to Parliament referendum looms.

title.children: Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price tells Press Club the Voice is 'flawed in its foundations'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: She accuses the PM of "ignoring" the marginalised. "You could say that by October 14 there would be some improvement for some people that are ignored," she says. "There are members in this group here today, Aboriginal women who have been trying to be heard by the Labor government but are being used as political footballs and ignored. "But if they were listen to right now, instead of pushing for a voice, if the government is we might have some kind of improvement. "By October 14 if this goes down, I have been working and will continue to work with my Coalition colleagues to make sure we will bring about the changes required and start from a position of reality."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Will the lives of Indigenous Australians be better the day after the referendum?'

children.content: She accuses the PM of "ignoring" the marginalised.
"You could say that by October 14 there would be some improvement for some people that are ignored," she says.
"There are members in this group here today, Aboriginal women who have been trying to be heard by the Labor government but are being used as political footballs and ignored.
"But if they were listen to right now, instead of pushing for a voice, if the government is we might have some kind of improvement.

"By October 14 if this goes down, I have been working and will continue to work with my Coalition colleagues to make sure we will bring about the changes required and start from a position of reality."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: She has been asked if the history of colonisation continues to impact Indigenous Australians. The answer: "No, there is no ongoing negative impacts of colonisation." "A positive impact, absolutely," she says. "I mean, now we have running water, readily available food, everything that my grandfather had when he was growing up, when he first thought white fellas in his adolescence, we now have."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'There is no ongoing negative impacts of colonisation'

children.content: She has been asked if the history of colonisation continues to impact Indigenous Australians.
The answer: "No, there is no ongoing negative impacts of colonisation."
"I mean, now we have running water, readily available food, everything that my grandfather had when he was growing up, when he first thought white fellas in his adolescence, we now have."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A reporter has noted the Senator's critisicm of the Voice because of the division she says it would create and questioned how it is different to the Indigenous Australians portfolio - which Senator Price is shadow minister for. Senator Price says "the Voice is contradictory in itself because it is about closing the gap but if you constitutionally enshrine it that suggests the gap will exist in perpetuity" "The same can be said for the portfolio that I hold. "I would hope to see that one day in our country, we would not require such a portfolio because if we do not have that portfolio it means that everybody is taking advantage of the same opportunities that our country has to offer"
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator hopes one day an Indigenous portfolio will not to exist

children.content: A reporter has noted the Senator's critisicm of the Voice because of the division she says it would create and questioned how it is different to the Indigenous Australians portfolio - which Senator Price is shadow minister for.
Senator Price says "the Voice is contradictory in itself because it is about closing the gap but if you constitutionally enshrine it that suggests the gap will exist in perpetuity"
"The same can be said for the portfolio that I hold.

"I would hope to see that one day in our country, we would not require such a portfolio because if we do not have that portfolio it means that everybody is taking advantage of the same opportunities that our country has to offer"

image.altText: people cross the street on a busy city street

items.synopsis: The local share market has opened slightly higher following mixed results on Wall Street, Myer has posted its best annual sales result since 2005, and the jobless rate remained steady in August at 3.7 per cent. Follow live.

title.children: Jobless rate steady for second-straight month, Myer reports best sales in 18 years, local shares higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Myer shares are down 1.2 per cent in afternoon trade. The stock is fetching about $0.62. The department store reported a 23 per cent jump in full-year statutory net profit after tax to $60.4 million. (There's quite a bit more on this from Emily further down the blog.) I had a look back Myer's historical share price performance. The stock peaked this year in March at about $1.13 — though its historical peak was in 2010 above $3 a share .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Myer shares fall despite best annual results in nearly 2 decades

children.content: in full-year statutory net profit after tax to
(There's quite a bit more on this from Emily further down the blog.)
I had a look back Myer's historical share price performance.
historical peak was in 2010 above $3 a share

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Workers at Chevron's Wheatstone and Gorgon liquefied natural gas (LNG) plants in Western Australia were set to begin rolling strike action today. They started downing tools at the plants for a few hours at a time last week, but from today are protected to stop work for 24 hours, for two weeks. Workers can determine how long they stop work for during each 24-hour period. Australia is the world's largest exporter of LNG — we mostly supply Asia. In fact, 16 per cent of Japan's energy comes from these projects. Since talks of industrial action by the 500 workers began last month, the price of spot LNG in Europe has been particularly volatile. If the strike action is prolonged and supply is constrained, it could see prices jump even higher. Research group EnergyQuest estimates the strike action could cost Chevron up to $76m in lost revenue a day. The workers are campaigning for better rostering (they currently do two weeks straight of 12-hour days, then fly home for two weeks off), more transparency about job titles and descriptions, less reliance on a labour-hire workforce, and better pay. Chevron and the union, Offshore Alliance, have been unable to reach an agreement and are before the Fair Work Commission. Chevron is pursuing an untested legal strategy to resolve the dispute and has applied to the Fair Work Commission with a hearing for that set down for September 22. The stop work action is likely to continue until then, however both parts have been instructed to keep negotiating.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chevron workers begin 24-hour strikes from today

The stop work action is likely to continue until then, however both parts have been instructed to keep negotiating.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As 500 Chevron workers take part in prolonged industrial action, they say consumers in Western Australia will not be impacted. The Gorgon and Wheatstone plants in the state's north have the capacity to separate supply and send it south to Perth and customers through the state, both residential and commercial. The workers have given an undertaking that through their protected industrial action they will continue to ensure LNG flows to domestic customers. You might recall, back in 2006 the then WA Premier, Alan Carpenter set up the gas reservation policy with the producers here in the state to ensure they committed 15 per cent of their production was reserved for Western Australian consumption. The WA government has so far stayed clear of weighing in on the Chevron worker dispute, saying it is for the Fair Work Commission to oversee. However, it has stated, should supply become constrained, it has levers it can pull to ensure households are not without energy. This dispute could have a way to run. Last year Shell workers walked off the job for 76 days, reportedly costing the company $1bn .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chevron workers say WA customers won't be affected by strike action
